abstracts.cdata!:
The Cyclone Rehabilitation Project in
            Madagascar was achieved. The main problem faced during the
            implementation period was the award of the reconstruction
            contracts for public buildings in Toamasina. The Ministry of
            Public Works proposed to divide the first phase in small
            contracts, in order to award these contracts to local film
            without excessive risks, and the Bank agreed with this
            approach. The result was relatively good, but with
            additional costs and delays. Nevertheless, it was clear that
            this amendment would not have been possible without the
            decree 84/236, requested by the Bank to expedite
            procurement. This was the only negative effect of this
            decree, otherwise very useful.

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed project is designed to:
            (i) contribute to the physical and economic rehabilitation
            of the areas damaged by cyclone Kamisy, particularly by
            restoring essential facilities before the next cyclone
            season.  It will; (ii) support institutional arrangements
            appropriate for efficient coordination of reconstruction
            efforts; and (iii) help develop measures to minimize the
            potential damage from natural disasters that could occur to
            these and other vulnerable areas of the country. The project
            will include:  (a) rehabilitation of Mahajanga and
            Antsiranana ports; (b) rehabilitation of Mahajanga and
            Antsiranana airports; and (c) rehabilitation of major roads
            affected by the cyclone (RN4, RN6, and RN8).  It will also
            provide for; (d) repairs to schools and other public
            buildings, administrative offices and state owned housing;
            (e) rehabilitation of FIFABE installations and equipment
            damaged by the cyclone in Marovoay; and (f) rehabilitation
            of JIRAMA's damaged power facilities in Mahajanga,
            Antsiranana, Toamasina, Nossi-Be, Ambatoboeni, and Marovoay.
            Finally, there will be funds for; (g) housing credit to
            private owners for the reconstruction of their houses
            damaged by the cyclone; and (h) consultant services,
            technical assistance, and an urban planning, drainage study.
